description: Client must send connection preface after TLS establishment

the connection preface starts with the string: PRI * HTTP/2.0

SM
Client preface must include a SETTINGS frame
Values greater than 16,384 MUST NOT be sent unless receiver has set larger SETTINGS_MAX_FRAME_SIZE
The frame type determines the format and semantics of the frame. Implementations MUST ignore and discard frames of unknown types.
A reserved 1-bit field. The semantics of this bit are undefined, and the bit MUST remain unset (0x00) when sending and MUST be ignored when receiving.
Receiving any frame other than HEADERS or PRIORITY on a stream in this (idle) state MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.

If an endpoint receives additional frames, other than WINDOW_UPDATE, PRIORITY, or RST_STREAM, for a stream that is in the half-closed (remote) state, it MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED.
An endpoint MUST NOT send frames other than PRIORITY on a closed stream.
Streams initiated by a client MUST use odd-numbered stream identifiers.
The identifier of a newly established stream MUST be numerically greater than all streams that the initiating endpoint has opened or reserved.
DATA frames MUST be associated with a stream.
If a DATA frame is received whose Stream Identifier field is 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.

If a DATA frame is received whose stream is not in the 'open' or 'half-closed (local)' state, the recipient MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (Tested in the idle state.)

If a DATA frame is received whose stream is not in the 'open' or 'half-closed (local)' state, the recipient MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (Tested in the half-closed (remote) state.)

If a DATA frame is received whose stream is not in the 'open' or 'half-closed (local)' state, the recipient MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (Tested in the closed state.)
A HEADERS frame without the END_HEADERS flag set MUST be followed by a CONTINUATION frame for the same stream.
If a HEADERS frame is received whose Stream Identifier field is 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
If a PRIORITY frame is received with a stream identifier of 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error of type PROTOCOL_ERROR
If a RST_STREAM frame is received with a stream identifier of 0x00, the recipient MUST treat this as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
A RST_STREAM frame with a length other than 4 octets MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type FRAME_SIZE_ERROR.
RST_STREAM frames MUST NOT be sent for a stream in the 'idle' state.
RST_STREAM frames MUST be associated with a stream.
When set, the ACK flag indicates that this frame acknowledges receipt and application of the peer's SETTINGS frame. When this bit is set, the frame payload of the SETTINGS frame MUST be empty.
The stream identifier for a SETTINGS frame MUST be zero (0x00).
A SETTINGS frame with a length other than a multiple of 6 octets MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type FRAME_SIZE_ERROR.
The initial value of SETTINGS_ENABLE_PUSH is 1. Any value other than 0 or 1 MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
For SETTINGS_INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE, values above the maximum flow-control window size of 2^31-1 (2147483647) MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type FLOW_CONTROL_ERROR.
The value advertised by an endpoint MUST be between initial value (2^14 = 16,384) and maximum allowed frame size (2^24-1 = 16,777,215 octets), inclusive.
An endpoint that receives a SETTINGS frame with any unknown or unsupported identifier MUST ignore that setting.
Unsupported settings MUST be ignored.
If a PING frame is received with a Stream Identifier field value other than 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
A receiver MUST treat the receipt of a WINDOW_UPDATE frame with a flow-control window increment of 0 as a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.

A sender MUST NOT allow a flow-control window to exceed 2^31-1 octets. If a sender receives a WINDOW_UPDATE that causes a flow-control window to exceed this maximum, it MUST terminate either the stream or the connection, as appropriate.
The sender MUST NOT send a flow-controlled frame with a length that exceeds the space available in either of the flow-control windows advertised by the receiver.
If a CONTINUATION frame is received with a Stream Identifier field of 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
A CONTINUATION frame MUST be preceded by a HEADERS, PUSH_PROMISE or CONTINUATION frame without the END_HEADERS flag set. (Using HEADERS frame with END_HEADERS flag set)
CONTINUATION frames MUST be associated with a stream.

If the END_HEADERS flag is not set, this frame MUST be followed by another CONTINUATION frame. A receiver MUST treat the receipt of any other type of frame or a frame on a different stream as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
Trailers MUST NOT include pseudo-header fields (Section 8.3).
Other frames (from any stream) MUST NOT occur between the HEADERS frame and any CONTINUATION frames that might follow.

An endpoint that receives a HEADERS frame without the END_STREAM flag set after receiving the HEADERS frame that opens a request or after receiving a final (non-informational) status code MUST treat the corresponding request or response as malformed (Section 8.1.1).
Field names MUST be converted to lowercase when constructing an HTTP/2 message.
Field names MUST NOT contain control characters (0x00-0x1F)
Field names MUST NOT contain ASCII SP (0x20)
Field names MUST NOT contain DEL character (0x7F)
Field names MUST NOT contain high byte characters (0x80-0xFF)
With the exception of pseudo-header fields (Section 8.3), which have a name that starts with a single colon, field names MUST NOT include a colon (ASCII COLON, 0x3a).
A field value MUST NOT contain line feed (ASCII LF, 0x0a). (Tested at the start of the value)
A field value MUST NOT contain carriage return (ASCII CR, 0x0d). (Tested at the start of the value)
A field value MUST NOT start with an ASCII whitespace character (ASCII SP or HTAB, 0x20 or 0x09).
A field value MUST NOT end with an ASCII whitespace character (ASCII SP or HTAB, 0x20 or 0x09).
A field value MUST NOT contain line feed (ASCII LF, 0x0a). (Tested at the middle of the value)
A field value MUST NOT contain line feed (ASCII LF, 0x0a). (Tested at the end of the value)
A field value MUST NOT contain carriage return (ASCII CR, 0x0d). (Tested at the middle of the value)
A field value MUST NOT contain carriage return (ASCII CR, 0x0d). (Tested at the end of the value)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing connection header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing proxy-connection header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing keep-alive header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing transfer-encoding header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing upgrade header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2)
The TE header field MAY be present in an HTTP/2 request; when it is, it MUST NOT contain any value other than 'trailers'.
Pseudo-header fields are not HTTP header fields. Endpoints MUST NOT generate pseudo-header fields other than those defined in this document.
Pseudo-header fields defined for responses MUST NOT appear in requests.

All pseudo-header fields sent from a client MUST appear in a field block before all regular field lines. Any request or response that contains a pseudo-header field that appears in a field block after a regular field line MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.1).

The same pseudo-header field name MUST NOT appear more than once in a field block. A field block for an HTTP request or response that contains a repeated pseudo-header field name MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.1). Tested with a request frame with the same value.

The same pseudo-header field name MUST NOT appear more than once in a field block. A field block for an HTTP request or response that contains a repeated pseudo-header field name MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.1). Tested with a request frame with different values.
Clients MUST NOT generate a request with a Host header field that differs from the ":authority" pseudo-header field.
':authority' MUST NOT include the deprecated userinfo subcomponent for "http" or "https" schemed URIs.
The ":path" pseudo-header field MUST NOT be empty for "http" or "https" URIs; "http" or "https" URIs that do not contain a path component MUST include a value of '/'.

All HTTP/2 requests MUST include exactly one valid value for the ":method", ":scheme", and ":path" pseudo-header fields, unless they are CONNECT requests (Section 8.5). An HTTP request that omits mandatory pseudo-header fields is malformed (Section 8.1.1). (Tested with :method missing)

All HTTP/2 requests MUST include exactly one valid value for the ":method", ":scheme", and ":path" pseudo-header fields, unless they are CONNECT requests (Section 8.5). An HTTP request that omits mandatory pseudo-header fields is malformed (Section 8.1.1). (Tested with :scheme missing)

All HTTP/2 requests MUST include exactly one valid value for the ":method", ":scheme", and ":path" pseudo-header fields, unless they are CONNECT requests (Section 8.5). An HTTP request that omits mandatory pseudo-header fields is malformed (Section 8.1.1). (Tested with :path missing)
A client cannot push. Thus, servers MUST treat the receipt of a PUSH_PROMISE frame as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
With the CONNECT method, the " :scheme" and " :path" pseudo-header fields MUST be omitted. (Tested with only :path present)
With the CONNECT method, the " :scheme" and " :path" pseudo-header fields MUST be omitted. (Tested with only :scheme present)
With the CONNECT method, the ":scheme" and ":path" pseudo-header fields MUST be omitted. (Tested with both present)
With the CONNECT method, The ":authority" pseudo-header field contains the host and port to connect to
Values greater than 16,384 MUST NOT be sent unless receiver has set larger SETTINGS_MAX_FRAME_SIZE. (server side)
The frame type determines the format and semantics of the frame. Implementations MUST ignore and discard frames of unknown types. (server side)
A reserved 1-bit field. The semantics of this bit are undefined, and the bit MUST remain unset (0x00) when sending and MUST be ignored when receiving. (server side)

If this stream (initially in the idle state) is initiated by the server, as described in Section 5.1.1, then receiving a HEADERS frame MUST also be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.  (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT send any type of frame other than HEADERS, RST_STREAM, or PRIORITY in the reserved (local) state. (server side)
Receiving any frame other than HEADERS or PRIORITY on a stream in this (idle) state MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)

If an endpoint receives additional frames, other than WINDOW_UPDATE, PRIORITY, or RST_STREAM, for a stream that is in the half-closed (remote) state, it MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT send frames other than PRIORITY on a closed stream. (server side)
Streams initiated by a server MUST use even-numbered stream identifiers. (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT send a RST_STREAM in response to a RST_STREAM frame (server side)
DATA frames MUST be associated with a stream. (server side) (server side)
If a DATA frame is received whose Stream Identifier field is 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)

If a DATA frame is received whose stream is not in the 'open' or 'half-closed (local)' state, the recipient MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (Tested in the idle state.) (server side)

If a DATA frame is received whose stream is not in the 'open' or 'half-closed (local)' state, the recipient MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (Tested in the half-closed (remote) state.) (server side)

If a DATA frame is received whose stream is not in the 'open' or 'half-closed (local)' state, the recipient MUST respond with a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type STREAM_CLOSED. (Tested in the closed state.) (server side)
A HEADERS frame without the END_HEADERS flag set MUST be followed by a CONTINUATION frame for the same stream. (server side)
If a HEADERS frame is received whose Stream Identifier field is 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)
If a PRIORITY frame is received with a stream identifier of 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)
After receiving a RST_STREAM on a stream, the receiver MUST NOT send additional frames for that stream, except for PRIORITY (server side)
If a RST_STREAM frame is received with a stream identifier of 0x00, the recipient MUST treat this as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)
A RST_STREAM frame with a length other than 4 octets MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type FRAME_SIZE_ERROR. (server side)
RST_STREAM frames MUST NOT be sent for a stream in the 'idle' state. (server side)
RST_STREAM frames MUST be associated with a stream. (server side)

When set, the ACK flag indicates that this frame acknowledges receipt and application of the peer's SETTINGS frame. When this bit is set, the frame payload of the SETTINGS frame MUST be empty. (server side)
The stream identifier for a SETTINGS frame MUST be zero (0x00). (server side)
A SETTINGS frame with a length other than a multiple of 6 octets MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type FRAME_SIZE_ERROR. (server side)

A server MUST NOT explicitly set this value (SETTINGS_ENABLE_PUSH) to 1. A server MAY choose to omit this setting (SETTINGS_ENABLE_PUSH) when it sends a SETTINGS frame, but if a server does include a value, it MUST be 0. (server side)
A server MUST NOT send a PUSH_PROMISE frame if it receives the SETTINGS_ENABLE_PUSH (0x02) parameter set to a value of 0. (server side)

For SETTINGS_INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE, values above the maximum flow-control window size of 2^31-1 (2147483647) MUST be treated as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type FLOW_CONTROL_ERROR. (server side)
The value advertised by an endpoint MUST be between initial value (2^14 = 16,384) and maximum allowed frame size (2^24-1 = 16,777,215 octets), inclusive. (server side)
An endpoint that receives a SETTINGS frame with any unknown or unsupported identifier MUST ignore that setting. (server side)
Unsupported settings MUST be ignored. (server side)
If the Stream Identifier field of a PUSH_PROMISE frame specifies the value 0x00, a recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)

The promised stream identifier MUST be a valid choice for the next stream sent by the sender (see 'new stream identifier' in Section 5.1.1). (Using Odd-numbered Stream ID (Invalid for Server)) (server side)
The promised stream identifier MUST be a valid choice for the next stream sent by the sender (see 'new stream identifier' in Section 5.1.1). (Using Already Used Stream ID) (server side)
The promised stream identifier MUST be a valid choice for the next stream sent by the sender (see 'new stream identifier' in Section 5.1.1). (Using Lower Stream ID) (server side)
A PUSH_PROMISE frame without the END_HEADERS flag set MUST be followed by a CONTINUATION frame for the same stream. (server side)
If a PING frame is received with a Stream Identifier field value other than 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)
A receiver MUST treat the receipt of a WINDOW_UPDATE frame with a flow-control window increment of 0 as a stream error (Section 5.4.2) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)

A sender MUST NOT allow a flow-control window to exceed 2^31-1 octets. If a sender receives a WINDOW_UPDATE that causes a flow-control window to exceed this maximum, it MUST terminate either the stream or the connection, as appropriate (server side).
The sender MUST NOT send a flow-controlled frame with a length that exceeds the space available in either of the flow-control windows advertised by the receiver. (server side)
A CONTINUATION frame MUST be preceded by a HEADERS, PUSH_PROMISE or CONTINUATION frame without the END_HEADERS flag set. (Using PUSH_PROMISE frame with END_HEADERS flag set) (server side)
If a CONTINUATION frame is received with a Stream Identifier field of 0x00, the recipient MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)
A CONTINUATION frame MUST be preceded by a HEADERS, PUSH_PROMISE or CONTINUATION frame without the END_HEADERS flag set. (Using HEADERS frame with END_HEADERS flag set) (server side)
CONTINUATION frames MUST be associated with a stream. (server side)

If the END_HEADERS flag is not set, this frame MUST be followed by another CONTINUATION frame. A receiver MUST treat the receipt of any other type of frame or a frame on a different stream as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. (server side)
Trailers MUST NOT include pseudo-header fields (Section 8.3). (server side)
Other frames (from any stream) MUST NOT occur between the HEADERS frame and any CONTINUATION frames that might follow. (server side)

An endpoint that receives a HEADERS frame without the END_STREAM flag set after receiving the HEADERS frame that opens a request or after receiving a final (non-informational) status code MUST treat the corresponding request or response as malformed (Section 8.1.1). (server side)
Field names MUST be converted to lowercase when constructing an HTTP/2 message. (server side)
Field names MUST NOT contain control characters (0x00-0x1F) (server side)
Field names MUST NOT contain ASCII SP (0x20) (server side)
Field names MUST NOT contain DEL character (0x7F) (server side)
Field names MUST NOT contain high byte characters (0x80-0xFF) (server side)
With the exception of pseudo-header fields (Section 8.3), which have a name that starts with a single colon, field names MUST NOT include a colon (ASCII COLON, 0x3a). (server side)
A field value MUST NOT contain line feed (ASCII LF, 0x0a). (Tested at the start of the value) (server side)
A field value MUST NOT contain carriage return (ASCII CR, 0x0d). (Tested at the start of the value) (server side)
A field value MUST NOT start with an ASCII whitespace character (ASCII SP or HTAB, 0x20 or 0x09). (server side)
A field value MUST NOT end with an ASCII whitespace character (ASCII SP or HTAB, 0x20 or 0x09). (server side)
A field value MUST NOT contain line feed (ASCII LF, 0x0a). (Tested at the middle of the value) (server side)
A field value MUST NOT contain line feed (ASCII LF, 0x0a). (Tested at the end of the value) (server side)
A field value MUST NOT contain carriage return (ASCII CR, 0x0d). (Tested at the middle of the value) (server side)
A field value MUST NOT contain carriage return (ASCII CR, 0x0d). (Tested at the end of the value) (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing connection header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2) (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing proxy-connection header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2) (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing keep-alive header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2) (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing transfer-encoding header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2) (server side)
An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing upgrade header field (RFC9113 Section 8.2.2) (server side)
The TE header field MAY be present in an HTTP/2 request; when it is, it MUST NOT contain any value other than 'trailers'. (server side)
Pseudo-header fields defined for requests MUST NOT appear in responses. (server side)

All pseudo-header fields sent from a server MUST appear in a field block before all regular field lines. Any request or response that contains a pseudo-header field that appears in a field block after a regular field line MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.1). (server side)

The same pseudo-header field name MUST NOT appear more than once in a field block. A field block for an HTTP request or response that contains a repeated pseudo-header field name MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.1). Tested with a response frame with the same value. (server side)

The same pseudo-header field name MUST NOT appear more than once in a field block. A field block for an HTTP request or response that contains a repeated pseudo-header field name MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.1). Tested with a response frame with different values. (server side)
Pseudo-header fields are not HTTP header fields. Endpoints MUST NOT generate pseudo-header fields other than those defined in this document. (server side)

For HTTP/2 responses, a single ":status" pseudo-header field is defined that carries the HTTP status code field. This pseudo-header field MUST be included in all responses, including interim responses; otherwise, the response is malformed. (server side)
The header fields in PUSH_PROMISE and any subsequent CONTINUATION frames MUST be a valid and complete set of request header fields. (server side)
In the PUSH_PROMISE frame, the server MUST include a method in the ":method" pseudo-header field that is safe and cacheable. (server side)
HTTP/2 does not support the 101 (Switching Protocols) informational status code (Section 15.2.2 of [HTTP]). (server side)
